reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 13, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Love the book..brings back a lot of memories..
reviews.reviewText: I was born in Poland in 1949..when my parents returned after being taken of the streets in 1940 as teens..and shipped to Germany to labor camp! It’s very refreshing to read a book that actually admits that not only Jews were sent and died in the camps. My mom’s cousin hid her Jewish girlfriend in her room..she was captured and died in Auschwitz…her friend escaped! Reading this book reminds brings me back asking my dad how he survived the hard work...he said he did it for the children he might have one day..since he never got to see his parents again.. both died while he was in the labor camp.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 13, 2024
reviews.reviewText: Was a great book! The story is captivating. Hopeful, sad, intriguing all in one book.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 27, 2023
reviews.reviewText: What I liked about this story was it was told from a completely different perspective. Typically these stories lean heavily towards anti Nazi and pro Allied forces. This was not the case with all the characters and the author did a very good job of handling the delicacy, although surely truthful feelings for some, on the subject. It certainly makes for interesting reading to try to see things from another's viewpoint.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 29, 2024
reviews.reviewText: Good character development, great story. Captured my interest immediately. Read it in just a little over a day, I couldn't put it down.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 3, 2024
reviews.reviewText: I loved this book. Although it was fiction, much written in it was familiar to me from stories my parents had told me all my life. Both of my parents were born in a Poland and had gone through the war. Alexsandra could have been my mother as a young girl, separated from her family. It was both heartbreaking and uplifting at the same time. I’d highly recommend this book

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 28, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars The Polish Nurse
reviews.reviewText: I read this book in one day, ignoring the household chores.There are a number of things in the book that I find somewhat unbelievable. Things that would be highly unlikely in that time and place. And the second to last main event ... After everything our brave heroine had endured, she would not have made that fateful choice. However, perhaps she went back and reclaimed what she had given up. Another chapter could be added bringing about satisfying closure.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 15, 2023
reviews.reviewText: The details in this book make it read as a true account which makes the ending believable and memorable. This also has a different POV than most holocaust novels..

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 20, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 3.0 out of 5 stars Not what I expected
reviews.reviewText: I'm 3/4 of the way through. It's not what I expectedThe book has very little to do with Lebensborn. It's about a truck accident and later working in Dresden.It's not terribly exciting

Aleksandra Vogel is 16 years old when she along with 17 other girls is kidnapped by the German conquerors from Lodz, Poland. They are being transported to Germany because they all have blond hair and blue eyes and unbeknownst to any of them, to take part in the Third Reich’s programme of having children for the so called pure race. What transpires is a story that makes the point that there are no winners in any war and through Aleksandra’s eyes, we see determination and strength of character can overcome all obstacles.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on January 4, 2024
reviews.reviewText: Not my usual story to read but wow !! Had me gripped from the very start Polish, German English American all entwined just brilliant now into the next

Remembering study of the war in school, I was taken back through the eyes and experience of Alexandria. It is hard to read what people went through, the horrible suffering that crippled their lives, but this story was written with thought, truth and with an eye to bring clarity to what is so distanced from us.

reviews.reviewTitle: Book 1 of the Brave women series.
reviews.reviewText: This is an excellent book depicting the strong women who survived the Second World War through all the hardships and danger that war brings to civilians, regardless of where they live and their resources.

This book will make you feel all the feels. That is the only way to explain how much I loved this book. It's a must read if you enjoy Historical fiction that is so well written you will not want to put it down!
